original_title: Sri Lanka’s inflation falls to 6.3-pct in July 2023
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s consumer price inflation fell to 6.3 percent in 12-months to July 2023, with food prices deflating 1.4 percent over the year, data from the state statistics office showed.
The widely watched Colombo Consumer Price Index fell 1.1 percent over the month of July.
Sri Lanka’s central bank has generated only 0.47 percent inflation in since September 2022, when deflationary open market operations began to show up in the balance of payments as a surplus.
The central bank from March also allowed the rupee to appreciate from 360 to around 295 to the US dollar.

The rupee has gone through two volatile ‘flexible exchange rate’ episodes, despite broadly deflationary policy due to what analysts say is an exchange rate policy error involving one sided interventions in an ad hoc peg arrangement, peddled to unstable countries by Western Mercantilists.
Over the past 12 months food prices fell absolutely by 1.4 percent, based on the index.
The rupee is still stronger than a year ago at 330 to the US dollar. (Colombo/July31/2023)
